tweets.text:
Anthropic just open-sourced the exact Skills library their own engineers use internally.

Stop building Claude workflows from scratch.

These are plug-and-play components that work across Claude Code, API, SDK, and VS Code copy once, deploy everywhere.

What's inside:

‚Üí Excel + PowerPoint generation out of the box
‚Üí File handling and document workflows
‚Üí MCP-ready subagent building blocks
‚Üí Pre-built patterns for multi-step automation
‚Üí Production templates you'd normally spend weeks writing

The old way: re-explain your workflow every single chat.

The new way: build a Skill once, Claude never forgets how you work.

100% Open Source. Official Anthropic release.

Repo: 
https://
github.com/anthropics/ski
lls
‚Ä¶

replies.text: The webapp-testing skill is the one I'm most curious about. Testing has been the hard part of any AI coding workflow ‚Äî agents write code fast but verifying it works is still manual. If this actually automates browser-based QA that's a bigger deal than the other skills combined.
replies.author: Ryan Craven

replies.text: Anthropic open-sourcing their internal Skills lib (Excel/PPT gen, MCP subagents, webapp-testing) turns one-shot chats into persistent, reusable workflows. Claude remembers your patterns forever.Biggest unlock: webapp-testing automating QA.Who's plugging it into their agent stack?

tweets.text: We've crossed the rubicon where AI generates most of our code, so we rebuilt our eng interviews for our new reality
tweets.author: Quinten Farmer

replies.text:
Our iOS lead Dan gives a great overview. The key takeaway: we can now get great signal on your ability to ship a complete feature 0 to 1 in the space of a single onsite day. 


https://
tolans.com/relay/how-we-h
ire-engineers-when-ai-writes-our-code
‚Ä¶

(also: we're hiring! 
https://
tolans.com/careers)
replies.author: Quinten Farmer

replies.text:
This is exactly what 
http://
ruwt.dev automates. Candidates get coding challenges with AI tools built in ‚Äî Claude, GPT, Gemini ‚Äî and you see which models they pick, how they prompt, and what it costs. Same signal as a morning onsite, but async and measurable.
replies.author: Israel Afangideh

replies.text: Great to see remote friendly versions of this eval, but in our case - we work together irl in SF - part of what we‚Äôre evaluating is how someone collaborates / communicates in person
replies.author: Quinten Farmer

replies.text: Job interviews, test questions, exercises, and skills assessments are all so contrived and dumb. Bring the candidate in and literally put them to work for an hour or two with team members.
replies.author: Ben Eng

replies.text: That‚Äôs‚Ä¶ exactly what this post describes
replies.author: Quinten Farmer

replies.text:
the hidden filter in this approach: you're not testing who can ship fastest with AI. you're testing who knows when to stop.

the best engineers in an AI-augmented interview will refuse to add features the spec didn't ask for, push back on requirements that smell wrong, and ship
replies.author: Vaclav Miliz√©

replies.text: this is the right move. interviewing people on how fast they type code was always dumb, but now it's completely pointless. the real skill is knowing what to build and why ‚Äî which was never testable in a leetcode round anyway. curious what you replaced it with

I think that we'll see much more wild variations of this going forward.

tweets.text:
OpenClaw is powerful but heavy.

ZeroClaw is a 3.4MB Rust-built alternative using <5MB RAM and booting in under 10ms 

Runs on a $10 Raspberry Pi Zero.
22+ AI providers.
Built-in sandboxing.
No external dependencies.
This is AI agents done lean.
tweets.author: Mervin Praison

replies.text: 3.4MB and <5MB RAM is wild. For edge deployments and local dev, this makes way more sense than spinning up a full OpenClaw instance. The Rust rewrite trend in AI tooling is real.

The loud story in 2025 was layoffs.

The quiet story in 2026 is demand growth.

- Citadel summarized the same signal:

tweets.text:
- Claude = coding. ($20/mo)
- Supabase = backend. (Free)
- Vercel = deploying. (Free)
- Namecheap = domain. ($12/yr)
- Stripe = payments. (2.9%/transaction)
- GitHub = version control. (Free)
- Resend = emails. (Free)
- Clerk = auth. (Free)
- Cloudflare = DNS. (Free)
- PostHog = analytics. (Free)
- Sentry = error tracking. (Free)
- Upstash = Redis. (Free)
- Pinecone =  vector DB. (Free)

Total monthly cost to run a startup: ~$20

There has never been a cheaper time to build.

replies.text: Facts
replies.author: CooperBaggs

replies.text:
OR

- VPS: Linode, DO, Hetzner, OVH, Vultr ($5/mo)
- Deploy: Kamal, Dokploy, or Coolify (Free)
- DNS, CDN & SSL: Cloudflare / Porkbun (Free | $0.81/mo)
- Storage: R2 (serving) + B2 (backup) ($1.14/mo)
- Comms: SES / Telnyx (Free | $5/mo)

Long-term: faster and cheaper.
